expanded_description: What happens when either employers or workers have market power in labor markets? In most of our analysis, we've assumed competitive labor markets where many firms compete for workers and many workers compete for jobs. But in reality, some labor markets feature powerful unions on the supply side or monopsony employers on the demand side. These market power conditions change the determination of wages and employment, often leading to different outcomes than the competitive model predicts. Understanding unions and monopsony is essential for analyzing real-world issues like minimum wage debates, labor strikes, and the effects of labor laws.

core_concept.principle: Market power in labor markets can exist on either the demand side (monopsony) or the supply side (unions). (1) Monopsony: A single buyer of labor in a market. The monopsonist faces an upward-sloping labor supply curve and must pay higher wages to attract more workers. The marginal cost of labor exceeds the wage. Profit maximization leads the monopsonist to hire fewer workers and pay a lower wage than in a competitive market. (2) Unions: Organizations that represent workers and bargain collectively with employers. Unions can increase wages above competitive levels through collective bargaining, and may also affect employment, productivity, and working conditions. (3) Bilateral monopoly: A market with both a monopsonist employer and a union. The outcome is indeterminate, depending on bargaining power. (4) Policy implications: Minimum wage laws can potentially increase both wages and employment in monopsony markets, contrary to the competitive model prediction.
core_concept.explanation: Think of a company town—one factory employs most of the local workers. That factory has monopsony power. If it wants to hire more workers, it must raise wages to attract them from other activities, and it must pay that higher wage to all workers. This makes the cost of hiring an extra worker higher than just that worker's wage. The factory hires fewer workers and pays lower wages than if many employers competed. Now imagine those workers form a union. The union bargains for higher wages. The outcome depends on who has more power—the monopsonist or the union.

sections.introduction: What happens when either employers or workers have market power in labor markets? In most of our analysis, we've assumed competitive labor markets where many firms compete for workers and many workers compete for jobs. But in reality, some labor markets feature powerful unions on the supply side or monopsony employers on the demand side. These market power conditions change the determination of wages and employment, often leading to different outcomes than the competitive model predicts. Understanding unions and monopsony is essential for analyzing real-world issues like minimum wage debates, labor strikes, and the effects of labor laws.

key_concept.definition: Market power in labor markets exists when either employers or workers can influence wages. (1) Monopsony: A market structure with a single buyer of labor. The monopsonist faces the market labor supply curve, which slopes upward—to hire more workers, it must raise the wage. Importantly, when it raises the wage to attract an additional worker, it must pay that higher wage to all existing workers. Therefore, the marginal cost of labor ($MFC$) exceeds the wage. The profit-maximizing monopsonist hires where $MRP = MFC$, then pays the wage on the supply curve at that employment level. This results in lower employment and a lower wage than in a competitive market. (2) Unions: Labor unions are organizations that bargain collectively with employers on behalf of workers. Unions can increase wages through: (a) Collective bargaining: Negotiating wages above competitive levels. (b) Strike threat: The credible threat of a strike gives unions bargaining power. (c) Reducing labor supply: Unions may restrict entry to occupations (licensing, apprenticeship requirements). (d) Increasing labor demand: Unions may promote the product or work to increase productivity. (3) Effects of unions: Unions typically raise wages for their members (union wage premium) but may reduce employment in the unionized sector. They may also increase productivity through improved worker-management relations or reduce productivity through restrictive work rules. (4) Bilateral monopoly: When a monopsonist employer faces a union, the outcome is indeterminate—it depends on the relative bargaining power of the two parties. The wage will be somewhere between the monopsony wage and the union's target, and employment may be higher than under pure monopsony. (5) Policy implications: In a monopsony market, a minimum wage set above the monopsony wage but below the competitive wage can actually increase both wages and employment—contrary to the competitive model prediction.
key_concept.context: The analysis of market power in labor markets has important implications for public policy. Debates over minimum wages, right-to-work laws, union organizing rights, and antitrust enforcement in labor markets all draw on these concepts. In AP Microeconomics, understanding monopsony and unions helps complete the picture of how labor markets can deviate from the competitive ideal and how policies might improve outcomes.

classifications.behavior: A monopsony exists when a single firm is the only employer in a labor market. This can occur in company towns, rural areas with one major employer, or for specialized labor where one firm dominates. The monopsonist faces the market labor supply curve, which is upward-sloping. To hire an additional worker, the firm must raise the wage. Crucially, it must pay this higher wage to all workers, not just the new one. Therefore, the marginal factor cost ($MFC$) of hiring an additional worker is greater than the wage. For example, if raising the wage from $\$10$ to $\$11$ attracts one more worker, and there are 10 existing workers, the cost of the new worker is $\$11$ plus the extra $\$1$ for each of the 10 existing workers ($\$10$), for a total $MFC$ of $\$21$. The profit-maximizing monopsonist hires where $MRP = MFC$, then pays the wage on the supply curve at that employment level. This results in lower employment and a lower wage than in a competitive market. Monopsony creates inefficiency—deadweight loss similar to monopoly.

image.alt: Monopsony graph showing MFC above supply, MRP = MFC determining employment, wage from supply
image.caption: Figure 8.5.4: Monopsony hires where MRP = MFC, pays lower wage than competitive market.

examples.explanation: In a town dominated by one coal mine or factory, that firm has monopsony power. It can pay lower wages than in competitive markets because workers have few alternatives.
Before free agency, sports leagues had monopsony power over players, leading to lower salaries than players' MRP.
A hospital that is the only major employer of nurses in a rural area may have monopsony power.

classifications.behavior: Labor unions are organizations that bargain collectively with employers over wages, benefits, and working conditions. Unions can raise wages above competitive levels through several mechanisms: (1) Collective bargaining: Negotiating wage floors above market-clearing levels. (2) Strike threat: The credible threat of a strike gives unions bargaining power. (3) Reducing labor supply: Unions may support licensing requirements, apprenticeship limits, or other barriers that restrict entry to occupations, shifting labor supply left and raising wages. (4) Increasing labor demand: Unions may promote union-made products, lobby for laws that increase demand for union labor, or work to increase productivity. The effects of unions are debated. Unions typically raise wages for their members (the union wage premium is estimated at 10-20%). However, higher wages may reduce employment in the unionized sector as firms substitute away from labor or relocate. Unions may also increase productivity through improved communication and reduced turnover, or decrease productivity through restrictive work rules and strikes.

image.alt: Union raising wage above equilibrium, creating surplus of labor
image.caption: Figure 8.5.5: Unions can raise wages above competitive levels, potentially creating unemployment.

examples.explanation: UAW bargains with automakers for wages and benefits above non-union levels in the auto industry.
Teachers' unions negotiate salary schedules, benefits, and working conditions with school districts.

characteristics: Single buyer, single seller of labor
classifications.behavior: Bilateral monopoly occurs when a monopsonist employer faces a union that represents all workers. This is a situation of double market power—both sides can influence the wage. The outcome is theoretically indeterminate; it depends on the relative bargaining power of the two parties. The union wants a high wage; the monopsonist wants a low wage. The actual wage will be somewhere between the monopsony wage (low) and the competitive wage or higher. Interestingly, employment may be higher than under pure monopsony because the union's pressure for higher wages may push the firm closer to the competitive employment level. The range of possible outcomes is bounded by the union's threat point (strike) and the firm's threat point (lockout or closure). Bilateral monopoly models help analyze labor negotiations in industries like professional sports, autos, and steel.

image.alt: Bargaining range between monopsony wage and union target
image.caption: Figure 8.5.6: Bilateral monopoly outcome depends on bargaining power.

examples.explanation: League owners (monopsony before free agency) bargained with players' union over salaries. Outcomes varied with bargaining power.
UAW bargains with automakers in a situation approximating bilateral monopoly.

principles.principle: In Monopsony, Marginal Factor Cost Exceeds the Wage
principles.statement: The key to understanding monopsony is recognizing that the marginal cost of hiring an additional worker ($MFC$) is greater than the wage. This happens because the monopsonist faces an upward-sloping labor supply curve—to attract another worker, it must raise the wage, and it must pay that higher wage to all existing workers. Therefore, $MFC = W + (\Delta W / \Delta L) \times L$. Graphically, the $MFC$ curve lies above the supply curve. The profit-maximizing monopsonist hires where $MRP = MFC$, then pays the wage on the supply curve at that employment level. This results in lower employment and a lower wage than in a competitive market where $W = MRP$. Monopsony creates a deadweight loss similar to monopoly.
principles.application: To analyze a monopsony, first derive the $MFC$ curve from the labor supply curve. Then find where $MRP = MFC$ to get employment, and read the wage from the supply curve. Compare to competitive outcome where $W = MRP$ at intersection of supply and $MRP$.
principles.example: If labor supply is $W = 10 + L$, then total cost $= W \times L = 10L + L^2$, so $MFC = 10 + 2L$. If $MRP = 50 - L$, set $50 - L = 10 + 2L$ → $40 = 3L$ → $L = 13.3$, $W = 23.3$. Competitive would set $W = MRP$: $10 + L = 50 - L$ → $2L = 40$ → $L = 20$, $W = 30$.

image.caption: Figure 8.5.7: In monopsony, marginal factor cost exceeds the wage.

principles.principle: Minimum Wage Can Increase Employment in Monopsony
principles.statement: In a competitive labor market, a minimum wage above equilibrium reduces employment. But in a monopsony market, a minimum wage set above the monopsony wage but below the competitive wage can actually increase employment. This surprising result occurs because the minimum wage overrides the monopsonist's ability to set wages below marginal revenue product. At the minimum wage, the firm can hire any number of workers up to the point where $MRP$ falls below that wage. The $MFC$ becomes constant at the minimum wage (up to the supply constraint), so the firm hires where $MRP$ equals the minimum wage. This can lead to both higher wages and higher employment. This theoretical possibility is often cited in debates over minimum wage policy, though empirical evidence on whether actual labor markets are monopsonistic is mixed.
principles.application: To analyze a minimum wage in a monopsony market, compare the minimum wage to the monopsony wage and the competitive wage. If it's between them, employment increases. If it's above the competitive wage, employment may decrease.
principles.example: In the previous example, monopsony wage $23.3$, competitive wage $30$. A minimum wage of $26$ would increase employment from $13.3$ to where $MRP = 26$: $50 - L = 26$ → $L = 24$, which exceeds competitive employment? Wait, that's above competitive $L=20$, so something's off—need to check supply constraint. At $W=26$, supply is $L = W - 10 = 16$, so firm can only hire 16 at that wage. So employment rises to 16, still above monopsony's 13.3.

image.alt: Minimum wage increasing employment in monopsony
image.caption: Figure 8.5.8: In monopsony, a minimum wage can increase both wages and employment.

principles.principle: Unions Can Both Raise Wages and Increase Productivity
principles.statement: The economic effects of unions are complex and debated. Traditional analysis focuses on unions as monopolies in labor supply that raise wages above competitive levels, potentially causing unemployment (the union wage premium). However, unions may also have positive effects: (1) Collective voice: Unions provide a mechanism for workers to express concerns and improve working conditions, reducing turnover and increasing productivity. (2) Shock effect: Higher wages may force firms to become more efficient, adopting better technology and management practices. (3) Reduced monitoring costs: Unions can help enforce contracts and reduce the need for expensive monitoring. (4) Training and apprenticeship: Unions often provide training that increases worker productivity. The net effect of unions on efficiency is ambiguous and likely varies across contexts. This complexity is why economists disagree about the overall impact of unions.
principles.application: When evaluating unions, consider both the wage effects and potential productivity effects. A union that raises wages but also increases productivity may not create inefficiency. The net effect on employment depends on whether productivity gains offset the wage increase.
principles.example: Some studies find that unionized construction workers are more productive than non-union workers, potentially offsetting the higher wages they receive.

image.alt: Balance scale weighing wage increases against productivity gains
image.caption: Figure 8.5.9: Unions may have both wage and productivity effects.

worked_examples.title: Monopsony Equilibrium
worked_examples.problem:
A monopsonist faces labor supply $W = 10 + 2L$ and has $MRP = 70 - 2L$.
a) Derive the marginal factor cost ($MFC$) function.
b) Find the monopsonist's profit-maximizing employment and wage.
c) Find the competitive employment and wage (where $W = MRP$).
d) Calculate the deadweight loss from monopsony.

step_by_step.explanation: Total labor cost $= W \times L = (10 + 2L)L = 10L + 2L^2$. $MFC = d(TC)/dL = 10 + 4L$.

DWL is the area between $MRP$ and supply from $L=10$ to $L=15$. At $L=10$, $MRP=70-20=50$, supply=$30$. At $L=15$, both=$40$. DWL = area of trapezoid? Actually triangle: height at $L=10$ is $50-30=20$, base $5$, DWL = $\frac{1}{2} × 20 × 5 = 50$.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Monopsony hires less and pays less than competitive market, creating deadweight loss.

worked_examples.title: Minimum Wage in Monopsony

image.caption: Figure 8.5.11: Analyze minimum wage effects in monopsony.

worked_examples.problem:
Using the same monopsony from the previous example ($W = 10 + 2L$, $MRP = 70 - 2L$), analyze the effects of minimum wages:
a) If a minimum wage of $35$ is imposed, what happens to employment?
b) If a minimum wage of $45$ is imposed, what happens?
c) Compare to the competitive outcome.

step_by_step.explanation: Monopsony wage was $30$, competitive $40$. $35$ is between them. At $W=35$, the firm can hire any workers as long as $MRP \geq 35$. $MRP = 70 - 2L \geq 35$ → $2L \leq 35$ → $L \leq 17.5$. But supply at $W=35$ is $L = (35-10)/2 = 25/2 = 12.5$. So maximum available at that wage is 12.5. Employment = 12.5 (higher than monopsony's 10).

$45$ is above competitive wage. $MRP \geq 45$ → $70 - 2L \geq 45$ → $2L \leq 25$ → $L \leq 12.5$. Supply at $W=45$: $L = (45-10)/2 = 35/2 = 17.5$. So demand constrained: employment = 12.5 (same as before? Actually 12.5, but note this is lower than competitive 15).
Minimum wage of $35$ increases both wage and employment relative to monopsony. Minimum wage of $45$ increases wage but leaves employment at 12.5, still below competitive 15.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) Employment increases to 12.5. b) Employment = 12.5 (same as a). c) Minimum wage between monopsony and competitive levels can increase employment; above competitive may reduce it.
worked_examples.concept_applied: In monopsony, moderate minimum wages can increase employment, unlike in competitive markets.

worked_examples.title: Union Effects

image.caption: Figure 8.5.12: Analyze union's effect on wages and employment.

worked_examples.problem:
A competitive labor market has demand $L_d = 100 - 2W$ and supply $L_s = 20 + 2W$.
a) Find the competitive equilibrium.
b) A union organizes and negotiates a wage of $\$25$. Find employment at this wage.
c) How many workers want to work at $\$25$? Is there unemployment?
d) If the union also negotiates a clause that requires firms to hire only union members and limits membership to 30 workers, what happens to wages and employment?

step_by_step.explanation: At $W=25$, $L_d = 100 - 50 = 50$. Employment = 50 (quantity demanded). $L_s = 20 + 50 = 70$. Surplus = 20 workers unemployed (or working elsewhere).

If only 30 workers can work (union members), then employment = 30. This is less than demand at that wage (50). Wage remains $25$, but now there is both unemployment (workers who want to work at $25$ but can't because of membership limit) and unfilled vacancies (firms want 50 but can only hire 30).

worked_examples.final_answer: a) $W=20$, $L=60$. b) Employment = 50. c) Supply = 70, unemployment = 20. d) Employment = 30, with both unemployment and unfilled vacancies.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Unions can raise wages above equilibrium, creating unemployment. Restricting membership can further reduce employment.

summary: Market power in labor markets can exist on either the demand side (monopsony) or the supply side (unions). Monopsony occurs when a single employer dominates a labor market. The monopsonist faces an upward-sloping labor supply curve, and the marginal factor cost ($MFC$) exceeds the wage. Profit maximization ($MRP = MFC$) leads to lower employment and a lower wage than in a competitive market. In monopsony, a minimum wage set above the monopsony wage but below the competitive wage can increase both wages and employment—contrary to the competitive model prediction. Unions are organizations that bargain collectively for workers. Unions can raise wages above competitive levels through collective bargaining, strike threats, and restricting labor supply. The union wage premium is typically 10-20%, but higher wages may reduce employment in the unionized sector. Unions may also affect productivity, with effects varying across contexts. Bilateral monopoly occurs when a monopsonist employer faces a union; the outcome is indeterminate, depending on relative bargaining power. Understanding market power in labor markets is essential for analyzing real-world issues like minimum wage debates, labor negotiations, and the effects of labor laws.
